titlStmt.titl: Drone Awareness and Perceptions: A Three Country Study, 2014: Canada Data

citation.biblCit: Cooper, A. 2014. Drone Awareness and Perceptions: A Three Country Study, 2014. [DDI Codebook]. Data Services. Queen's University, Kingston, Ontario, Canada: [producer and distributor].

titlStmt.titl: Drone Awareness and Perceptions: A Three Country Study, 2014: Canada Data

prodStmt.prodPlac: Angus Reid Global, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada

citation.biblCit: Angus Reid Global, Drone Awareness and Perceptions: A Three Country Study, 2014. Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada: Angus Reid Global [producer]. Data Services, Queen's University [distributor].

stdyInfo.abstract:
This survey aimed to understand awareness and perceptions surrounding the use of drones to identify and collect information in Canada, United States, and United Kingdom. The questions asked individuals whether they had a basic awareness of various Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAV) applications, as well as assessed support for how they are being used and in what scenarios.

The survey was conducted by the polling company Vision Critical in January 2014 based on a set of questions developed by the Surveillance Drones Research Team, Surveillance Studies Centre, Queen's University.

There are three separate data files for this survey - Canada, Unites States, and United Kingdom.

sumDscr.universe: Participants for Angus Reid Global surveys are taken from American, British, and Canadian adults who are members of the Springboard America, Springboard UK, and Angus Reid Forum panels.

dataColl.sampProc: Participants for Angus Reid Global surveys are taken American, British, and Canadian adults who are members of the Springboard America, Springboard UK, and Angus Reid Forum panels.
dataColl.collMode: Online survey with a balanced random sampling of online panels in each country.
dataColl.collSitu:
A split cell (monadic) design was used to separate perceptions surrounding forms of information identification and collection in general from perceptions surrounding information identification and collection when drones are used.

The four topics were:

  • Piloted Aircraft (Canada n=761; UK n=502; US n=760)
  • Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (Canada n=761; UK n=502; US n=751)
  • Autonomous Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (Canada n=762; UK n=500; US n=753)
  • Control (Canada n=761; UK n=504; US n=758)
dataColl.weight: Post data collection, results were weighted to match population age, gender, and regional distribution.

useStmt.citReq: The publishing of analysis and results from research using this data is permitted in research communications such as scholarly papers, journals and the like. The author(s) of these communications are required to cite the author as the source of the data and to indicate that the results or views expressed are those of the author/authorized user.
useStmt.disclaimer: The original collector of the data bears no responsibility for use of this collection or for interpretation or inference upon such use.

othrStdyMat.relMat:
A Report to the Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada, under the 2013-2014 Contributions Program. April 2014.
Suveillance Drones: Privacy Implications of the Spread of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) in Canada

Automated-license plate recognition

var.labl: Using an aerial vehicle that is flying so high, or is so small, that you cannot see it

Using an aerial vehicle that is flying so high, or is so small, that you cannot see it
